title: Which European city is winning the race to poach business from London?
text:
"Over time, we expect the headline numbers of firms, staff and business to increase significantly as the dust settles on Brexit, temporary arrangements agreed between the EU and UK expire, and local regulators require firms to increase the substance of their local operations," the report said.

Australian banks and insurers are among those who have prepared for Brexit by beefing up their EU presence. Commonwealth Bank has opened an office in Amsterdam, Macquarie has sought licences in Dublin, and Westpac has requested a licence to operate in Frankfurt. National Australia Bank has been looking at Paris. ANZ already has branches in France and Germany.

Janus Henderson has opened an office in Luxembourg, and QBE has create a new entity, QBE Europe, based in its existing office in Brussels.

New Financial isn't the only organisation monitoring the market. Accounting firm EY last month estimated that 7000 jobs had been shifted out of London to date, along with £1 trillion in assets.

City of London Lord Mayor Peter Estlin, though, recently painted a different picture, telling The Australian Financial Review that 35,000 new jobs had been created in the City since Brexit.

And Citigroup's European head David Livingstone recently told the Financial Times that he was confident in London's future, even though Brexit had cost the bank $US100 million ($146 million) as it shifted staff to Dublin, Frankfurt and Paris.

Advertisement

"There is a degree of EU sovereignty about this ... they want the euro market to be located within the eurozone," the Australian-born executive said. "So, sure, there'll be business which leaves London, but I don't think London fundamentally changes as the regional financial centre."

Bank of America, meanwhile, has spent $US400 million shifting hundreds of staff to Dublin and Paris.

EY reckons that British financial services groups had by June spent a collective £4 billion preparing for Brexit.

In better news for Britain, London's share of global foreign exchange trading increased by six percentage points to 43 per cent in the three years to 2019, a Bank for International Settlements study showed in September.

The City also reached a 50 per cent market share of over-the-counter derivatives trading, up from 38 per cent three years ago.
description: As Brexit forces banks, hedge funds and asset managers to shift staff, several rival centres are sharing the spoils.
